RepairAreaTip: Damp on a wall at a low level could be rising damp. You may see discoloured patches on the lower part of the your wall on the inside, the floor around that area may also be damp. Check the outside of the wall and make sure that it is free from any earth and debris, as this can contribute to rising damp.
Desc: Damp, Damp patches on the wall, .

RepairAreaTip: Damp on a wall at a low level could be rising damp. You may see discoloured patches on the lower part of the your wall on the inside, the floor around that area may also be damp. Desc: Damp, Damp patches on the wall, .

RepairAreaTip: If the damp patch is on the ceiling directly below your roof, the most likely cause of the damp patch is a roof leak. We recommend that you look at the roof, if you can, and check that there no slates or tiles missing. If the ceiling is not directly below a roof, you may have a leak from a pipe. We recommend you check the room above the area to see if you can see anything obvious.
Desc: Damp, Damp patches on the ceiling, .

We recommend you check the room above the area to see if you can see anything obvious.
Desc: Damp, Damp patches on the ceiling, .

RepairAreaTip: Surface damp and mould is usually caused by condensation, this will usually happen in the kitchen or bathroom where hot water makes the atmosphere steamy, or where water is running down the inside of the windows. You can reduce condensation by keeping rooms warm and well ventilated, use an extractor fan (if one is fitted) or keep a window open. Make sure that any vents in the windows are kept open and wipe away small patches of mould regularly.
RepairArea: Damp and black mould of walls or ceiling
Desc: Damp, Damp and black mould of walls or ceiling, .
